content:
Sure! An example of an intrusive igneous rock is granite. Granite forms when magma solidifies deep within the earth's crust, and is typically composed of coarse-grained minerals like quartz, feldspar, and mica. 

An example of an extrusive igneous rock is basalt. Basalt forms when lava solidifies on the surface of the earth, and is typically composed of fine-grained minerals like olivine, pyroxene, and plagioclase. Basalt is commonly found in volcanic regions and is used to create a variety of materials, including paving stones and building blocks.
